D A T A A R T I C L E
Sediment particle tracking data for the Carpathian
reservoir under climate and land use change scenarios
Ewa Szalińska 1
| Paweł S. Hachaj 2 | Monika Szlapa 2 | Paulina Orlińska-Woźniak 3 |
Paweł Wilk 3

the original work is properly cited.

Creator: Paweł S. Hachaj, Monika Szlapa, Paulina Orlińska-Woźniak, Ewa Jakusik, Paweł Wilk, Ewa Szalińska
Dataset correspondence: paulina.wozniak@imgw.pl
Title: Sediment particle distribution in a dammed reservoir under climate and land use scenarios (Carpathian Mts.)
Publisher: Mendeley Data
Publication year: 2022
Resource type: Data set
Version: 2.0
1 Faculty of Geology, Geophysics and
Environmental Protection, AGH
University of Krakow, Krakow, Poland
2 Faculty of Environmental and Power
Engineering, Cracow University of
Technology, Krakow, Poland
3 Institute of Meteorology and Water
Management, National Research
Institute, Warsaw, Poland
Correspondence
Ewa Szalińska, Faculty of Geology,
Geophysics and Environmental
Protection, AGH University of Krakow,
A. Mickiewicza Av. 30, 30-059 Krakow,
Poland.
Email: eszalinska@agh.edu.pl
Funding information
"Excellence initiative-research

of Krakow, Grant/Award Number:
501.696.7996/L-34
Abstract
Although the Carpathian Mts. area is considered as extremely prone to sur-
face erosion which results in capacity loss of the dammed reservoirs, a lack
of data to follow details of this process is perceivable. The research of the se-
lected sediment fractions transport tracking was conducted using the capa-
bilities of the digital platform-Macromodel DNS (Discharge-Nutrient-Sea)
for the catchment with drinking water reservoir in the Polish part of Western
Carpathian. The continuity of sediment transport simulation in two hydrologi-
cally different elements of the catchment-the river and the reservoir-was
possible due to consolidation of two models in the platform-SWAT (Soil &
Water Assessment Tool) and AdH/PTM (Adaptive Hydraulics Model/Particle
Tracking Model). The result of those modules' integration was a database for
tracking the individual sediment fractions delivered to the reservoir and de-
posited in specific reservoir zones. The implementation of climate and land
use change scenarios allowed additionally to analyse the estimation of those
processes in the future. The simulation outcomes consist of daily flows and
monthly sediment loads at the reservoir inflow and the individual sediment
particle fractions deposition location inside of the reservoir.
K E Y W O R D S
AdH/PTM, Carpathian river, dammed reservoir, macromodel DNS, sediment fractions, SWAT
text.body:
1 | INTRODUCTION
Storage capacity of dammed reservoirs is being lost world-
wide due to sedimentation (Kondolf et al., 2014) and this
loss is estimated at 1% yearly of their total volume, although
in the areas particularly prone to erosion it can reach
much higher values (Bekri et al., 2021; Jain, 2005; Perera
et al., 2023; Rahmani et al., 2018; Sedláček et al., 2022).
Moreover, the forecasted changes in precipitation, tem-
peratures, and land use suggest that the intensity of this
phenomenon may increase significantly (Bussi et al., 2021;
Dethier et al., 2022; Pesci et al., 2023; Pieron et al., 2021;
Wei et al., 2020). One of the areas particularly affected by
erosional problems in Europe is covered by the range of
Western Carpathian Mts., shared mainly by Slovakia and
Poland, but also partially by Czech Republic, Hungary
and Austria (Absalon et al., 2023; Gil et al., 2021; Halecki
et al., 2018; Oskoruš et al., 2023). Dynamic changes, land
use and climate occurring in this area have a significant
impact on both the land and bed river phase of the sed-
iment transport (Kijowska-Strugała, 2019; Wilk, 2022).
Since the 1930s, several dammed reservoirs have been
built in the area of the Western Carpathians disrupting
sediment transport continuity, trapping bed material and
a majority of suspended sediment. Although reservoir sed-
imentation problems are reported frequently in different
climate zones (e.g. Asthana & Khare, 2022; Iradukunda
& Bwambale, 2021; Reisenbüchler et al., 2021; Ren
et al., 2021), they are discussed mainly in terms of sedi-
ment loads delivered into the reservoirs while the aspect
of tracking delivered particles inside of a reservoir is rarely
reported. Majority of the catchment modelling tools treat
reservoirs as points which results in load simulations only
for the opening/closing profiles (e.g. Kwarteng et al., 2021;
Mamede et al., 2018; Rabelo et al., 2021; Shrestha
et al., 2021; Zajac et al., 2017). Such an approach leads to
a vast generalization impairing knowledge on grain size
fraction transport issues and particle deposition areas.
Moreover, transport of sediments in river and reservoir
conditions has been usually studied using tools operating
at different spatial and temporal scales, often treating them
as separate units or largely generalizing the relationship
between them (Wilk, 2022). Meanwhile, a river-reservoir
arrangement is a dynamic, complex and, above all, integral
system with deep interactions, where processes responsi-
ble for the sediment transport are stochastic and variable.
To properly reflect them, it is necessary to combine various
modelling tools. However, such an integration is difficult
and limited by specific model codes, as well as formats and
data exchange between models. Moreover, there is still a
very limited use of such a solution (Guzman et al., 2015;
Nazari-Sharabian et al., 2019; Shin et al., 2019), especially
in mountainous areas.
The objective of this study is to present detailed infor-
mation on the sediment loads introduced to the reservoir
and their subsequent transport in the dammed reservoir
(Dobczycki Reservoir) located on the Raba River in south-
ern Poland (Western Carpathians). The presented data-
base results from the integration of two models SWAT
and AdH/PTM on a common digital space-Macromodel
(DNS)-allowing for detailed monitoring of sediment
transport in each zone of the dammed reservoir. This tool
allows the user to assess which zones of the reservoir are
currently, and will be in the future, most vulnerable to loss
of capacity and how the deposition areas of individual
fractions will change in the future climate and land use
scenarios. The information contained in this database can
also be successfully used in the development of models for
subsequent catchments in the analysed area and help in
the assessment of the impact of climate change on the ex-
isting or planned reservoirs in the Carpathians. Moreover,
the presented database makes an important step for model
integration, using their best features for a better under-
standing of current and future threats to the operation of
dammed reservoirs.
2 | MATERIALS AND METHODS
2.1 | Study area
The study area covers the area of the upper Raba River
catchment which belongs to the Polish part of the Western
Carpathians, covering sub-catchments of the upper Vistula
River (Soła, Skawa, Raba, Dunajec, Biała, Wisłoka and
Wisłok Rivers) (Wyżga, Zawiejska, & Hajdukiewicz, 2016;
Wyżga, Zawiejska, & Radecki-Pawlik, 2016). These catch-
ments have many common features, including the moun-
tainous character of their upper parts manifesting itself
in a quick reaction to rainfall and high dynamics of sur-
face runoff (Korpak et al., 2021; Wyżga et al., 2021). The
similar characteristic is also shared by the catchments on
the Slovak side [Rusnák et al., 2018; Barabas et al., 2017;
Lehotský et al., 2013].
The Raba River flows 131 km from its source in the
Gorce Mountain range (780 m a.s.l.) to the Vistula River
(180 m a.s.l.) and features a dammed reservoir (Dobczyce
Reservoir) at 60 km from the source (Figure 1). The part of
the Raba River catchment, localized upstream from the res-
ervoir, covers an area of 768 km 2 with 43% of the area cov-
ered by slopes over 25% and overgrown by forest. The river
flows are characterized by very large amplitudes, with max-
imum values recorded in the snow melt period, and early-
summer long-lasting rainfall events. The studied catchment
is covered generally by clays, and its lower slopes are used
mostly for agricultural activities (over 40%). The Dobczyce
text.note: 20496060, 2024, 4, Downloaded from https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/gdj3.242 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
Reservoir was created mainly to provide drinking water
for approx. half a million people, and to regulate the river
flows. The reservoir has an area of approx. 10.7 km 2 (8 km by
1.6 km), and an average depth of 12 m (maximum of 35 m)
(Mazurkiewicz-Boron, 2016; Wilk-Woźniak et al., 2021).
The reservoir is divided into four zones (Figure 3) includ-
ing a river part (A), backwater (B), Myślenice basin (C) and
Dobczyce basin (D). The section downstream from the res-
ervoir has been also included in the current approach and
labelled as OUT. The entire area of the upper Raba River
catchment belongs to the Carpathian climatic region with
an average annual air temperature around 7°C (ampli-
tude of 21°C) and the average rainfall ranging from about
700 mm to about 1600 mm at the higher altitudes (Wypych
et al., 2018).
2.2 | Modelling tools
The study used SWAT and AdH/PTM models, combined
as modules on a digital platform-Macromodel DNS. The
SWAT module (version 2012.10_2.19) has been used to
simulate sediment yields from the catchment (land phase)
and sediment loads (river phase) delivered to the reservoir
in Myślenice calculation profile. Moreover, the SWAT
module has been also used to estimate the sediment loads
discharged into the dammed reservoir in future time
horizons under climate and land use changes. The use of
SWAT together with AdH/PTM combined the tracking of
the mass load (Euler approach) and the individual par-
ticle (Lagrange's approach) (Figure 2). For this purpose,
a number of representative particles were generated for
each fraction of suspended sediment, proportional to the
respective mass load calculated by the SWAT module for a
given month. This procedure was performed for the three
fractions of the sediment load, i.e. two mineral ones: CLAY
0-0.004 mm, SILT 0.004-0.062 mm and a mineral-organic
one: SMAG 0.03 mm. The sediment source generates the
set of particles in a three-dimensional Gaussian cloud
specified by median grain size (d) and standard deviation
(dev). Representative particles imitate the incoming sedi-
ment, but each of the particles is considered separately
in the computational process (Lagrange's approach). To
cover the above fractional ranges, the following param-
eters were used: CLAY d = 0.002 mm (dev = 1.25), SILT
d = 0.05 mm (dev = 1.2), SMAG d = 0.03 mm (no devia-
tion). The number of particles is proportional to the mass
of the sediment load supplied by the Raba River (SWAT
result). Consequently, these three individual sediment
fractions distribution has been tracked using the AdH/
PTM module (Surface-water Modelling System model
package 13.2 by AQUAVEO) in individual zones of the
dammed reservoir. Hydraulic conditions in the dammed
reservoir for sediment load scenarios have been modelled
F I G U R E 1 The upper Raba River catchment with slopes, type of use, soil, division into sub-basins and a dammed reservoir divided into
four zones.

with use of the AdH module, while the particle transport
within the dammed reservoir has been simulated with the
use of the PTM module.
2.3 | Calculation of a sediment load
introduced into a dam reservoir
2.3.1 | Hydrological model set-up
Current and future sediment loads introduced into the
Dobczyce Reservoir have been calculated with the use of
the SWAT model which is a physical, semi-distributed
continuous-time modelling tool, running on a daily and
sub-daily time steps (Arnold et al., 2012). In this model,
continuous simulation of hydrological processes and re-
lated surface runoff, erosion, deposition and degradation
responsible for sediment transport are run in the hydro-
logic response units (HRUs) designated on the base of
land cover, soil and slope uniformity for particular units.
As the basis for this model, numerous geospatial data nec-
essary have been used, including, among others, land el-
evation (topography), soil and land covers and the stream
network (Table 1).
In the original approach (Orlińska-Woźniak
et al., 2020a), the entire Raba River catchment was sub-
jected to the procedure of delimitation based on DEM,
which resulted in 36 sub-catchments (with an average
area of 4000 ha) consisting of 902 HRUs, where further
calculations were made. In the current approach, only sub-
catchments upstream from the Dobczyce Reservoir (17),
constituting the upper part of the main catchment, have
been taken into consideration (74,900 ha). The share of in-
dividual types of land use, soils and slopes in the analysed

text.body:
area is shown in Figure 3. Sub-catchments located in
this area are characterized by the highest risk of soil loss,
which is presented in detail by Szalińska et al. (2020) and
Orlińska-Woźniak et al. (2020a).
The SWAT tool allows the user to select various meth-
ods and equations to simulate the individual components
of the water balance, depending on the availability of
input data. In the current approach, the following el-
ements of the SWAT module were used to simulate the
processes responsible for surface runoff and erosion in the
land phase as well as deposition and degradation in the
river bed phase:
• SCS-CN (USDA Soil Conservation Service) empirical
model (Bartlett et al., 2016; Shi & Wang, 2020), which
is mainly based on soil properties, land use and hydro-
logical conditions and is widely used for surface runoff
estimation with daily precipitation as input.
• Modified universal soil loss equation (MUSLE) (Vigiak
et al., 2015), which is an example of a compromise be-
tween empirical and physical algorithms in the SWAT
module. It can predict soil erosion at the HRU level,
resulting in soil particle transport. MUSLE is a modi-
fied version of USLE based on the runoff characteris-
tics as the best single indicator for predicting sediment
performance at the basin outlet, and factors influencing
soil erosion. By using the energy of surface runoff, not
rainfall, MUSLE is suitable for use on a daily basis to
estimate the sediment efficiency, and takes into account
sediment deposition in HRU.
• Muskingum method, which directs water in a network
of canals using Manning's equation (Her et al., 2017;
Wilk, 2022). The suspended sediment transported with
the water is subject to deposition and degradation pro-
cesses. The SWAT module offers four methods of sim-
ulating these processes (Bagnold, Kodoatie, Molinas
and Wu, Yang Sand and Gravel). In the current study,
the Kodoatie method was chosen because it allowed
for analysing sediment load by individual fractions.
Moreover, it is considered to be particularly effective for
suspended and small sediment particles. This method
has been described as an empirical optimized sedi-
ment transport equation, using non-linear optimiza-
tion and field data for different river sediment particle
sizes (Lu & Chiang, 2019; Yen et al., 2017) according to
Equation (1):

• Penman-Monteith equation (Parajuli et al., 2018) was

75 stations located directly in the basin, and within
20 km from its borders), humidity, wind speed and solar
radiation were used as input data for the catchment
model.
2.3.2 | SWAT module
calibration and validation
Model calibration and validation were performed using
SWAT-CUP and the SUFI-2 algorithm (Tejaswini &
Sathian, 2018). The Latin Hypercube (LH-OAT) (Zadeh
et al., 2022) was used to identify the most influential
model parameters. The model was calibrated and veri-
fied in terms of calculation profiles closing the upper
(Myślenice) and lower parts (Proszówki) of the catchment
area (Figure 4), using the 25-year flow data (1993-2017)
obtained from the Institute of Meteorology and Water
Management and the total suspended sediment concen-
trations from the National Monitoring System for the 13-
year period (2005-2017) (Table 3).
Due to the low frequency of the available sediment
monitoring data (12 times a year), the LOAD ESTimator
(LOADEST)
(https:// pubs. er. usgs. gov/ publi cation/
tm4A5 ) program was used to reliably estimate continuous
loads data from measurements for calibration purpose.
Validation of the model was carried out for the Stradomka
River (a right-bank tributary of the Raba River), for which
suspended sediment monitoring measurements were
available. Four statistical measures were used to assess
the fit of the model to the monitoring results: determina-
tion coefficient (R 2 ) (Piepho, 2019), efficiency coefficient
of the Nash-Sutcliffe model (NSE) (Knoben et al., 2019),
percentage of load (PBIAS) (Mengistu et al., 2021) and
Kling-Gupta efficiency (KGE) (Knoben et al., 2019). The
respective ranges of these measures were based on (Libera
& Sankarasubramanian, 2018; Patil & Stieglitz, 2015; Xing
et al., 2018) are presented in Table 2.
For flow calibration R 2 , NSE and KGE classified the
model performance as good and very good, and PBIAS
obtained satisfactory values (Table 3). Calibration of sed-
iment for the upper Raba catchment showed satisfactory
results for R 2 and NSE and very good and good for PBIAS
and KGE. Better results were obtained for the lower part
of the catchment, where the efficiency of the model can be
considered very good (for R 2 ) and good (for NSE, PBIAS
and KGE). Model validation (for R 2 , PBIAS and KGE)
showed good model results, while only NSE obtained a
satisfactory value. For sediment, according to R 2 , NSE and
KGE, the performance of the model can be considered sat-
isfactory and good according to PBIAS (Table 3).
The finally calibrated and validated model was used for
the baseline scenario simulation of sediment loads for the
calculation profile of Myślenice, which was estimated for
the following fractions (CLAY, SILT and SMAG).
2.3.3 | Variant scenarios
The climate variant scenarios for the Raba River catch-
ment were prepared for the Krakow-Balice synoptic sta-
tion data based on the Development of Urban Adaptation
Plans (UAP) for cities with more than 100,000 inhabit-
ants in Poland (http:// 44mpa. pl/? lang= en). Data from
the UAP project with monthly time step for precipitation
and temperature were used to calculate delta change rates
for all climate change scenarios. The distance between
Kraków-Balice station and the Myślenice calculation pro-
file (29 km) and altitude difference (150 m) permitted to
use these data without necessity of any transposition, ac-
cording to both the World Meteorological Organization
(WMO) and IMGW-PIB recommendations (Derek
et al., 2014; WMO, 2017, 2018).
The UAP project predictions have been based on the
data from the Euro-CORDEX and Regional climate
models -RCM (on a regular grid with a resolution of
12.5 km) (Dosio, 2016; Rummukainen, 2016)-and the
Global Climate Models-GCM (Wootten et al., 2017; Yang
et al., 2019)-used to determine the boundary conditions.
Finally, an average of the ensemble, built of the 14 selected
F I G U R E 4 Comparison of measured and predicted monthly flows and sediment loads at calculation profiles Myślenice and Proszówki
during the calibration period (2005-2017).
text.note: 20496060, 2024, 4, Downloaded from https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/gdj3.242 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
RCM models (Table 4) as the best reflecting the local an-
nual cycle of both precipitation and air temperature (no
gross errors detected), has been used.
In the UAP project, the accuracy of the Euro-CORDEX
forecasts was established by comparison with data from
historical observations of IMGW-PIB for the same period
of time (2006-2015). For the average annual rainfall and
temperature, the error rate did not exceed 1% (CV = 0.42).
For daily data, models giving gross errors, i.e. shifts of
the modelled series in the annual cycle, were rejected.
The analyses were performed for both the RCP4.5 and
RCP8.5 scenarios. Statistical postprocessing (downscal-
ing) was a part of a UAP project and performed using the
tools available in the R environment (R, 2020). The error
reduction was established by analysing each model of
Euro-CORDEX for each scenario and each meteorologi-
cal parameter for corresponding grid meshes of Kraków-
Balice included in the UAP project. The climate condition
analysis in the UAP project covered two future time hori-
zons: short-term perspective-calculated as an average of
the 2026-2035 period, and a long-term perspective-cal-
culated as an average of the 2046-2055 period. Therefore,
four climate variant scenarios, with a monthly time step,
were prepared to combine the RCP predictions and ad-
opted time horizons (Table 5).
Along with the climate change predictions, the land use
future changes, modified in SWAT model by the Landuse
Update tool, have also been taken into consideration and
were combined with each RCP scenario, since they occur
concurrently. Land use changes predictions were based
on results of the FORECOM project (Kolecka et al., 2017;
Kozak et al., 2017), and transposed into the analysed area
with use of the DYNA-Clue model for the future time
horizon of 2060 (Kozak et al., 2017; Price et al., 2017).
The FORECOM project was implemented on the basis of
Swiss Contribution covering the Carpathian region, an-
alysing the past of land use changes since the 19th cen-
tury, and the future in three forecast scenarios. Land use
maps of the Polish Carpathians included forecasts until
2060 with the resolution of 50 m. The 'trend' scenario as-
sumed a further development trend that is currently ob-
served, the 'liberal' scenario assumed that changes are
dictated by market mechanisms and the 'environmental'
scenario assumed that policies and interventions aimed
at protecting the environment, landscape and biodiversity
play an important role in land use changes. The project
concluded that the area of the Carpathians will develop
at different rates. Using data on population distribution
from the Central Statistical Office (GUS, 2022) and on
forest cover and slopes from the Corine Land Cover, sub-
basins have been classified into appropriate groups rep-
resenting individual forecast scenarios (trend, liberal and
environmental) (Orlińska-Woźniak et al., 2020b). Zones

designed. The upper Raba River catchment covered two
zones; for part of subbasins the trend scenario has been

and urban areas, respectively by 30% and 15%) has been
assumed (Orlińska-Woźniak et al., 2020b). In this way,

created.
2.4 | Sediment particle distribution
in the dammed reservoir
2.4.1 | Hydraulic and particle tracking
models set-up
To execute the sediment transport and deposition simu-
lations in the Dobczyce Reservoir, the AdH/PTM model
(Hachaj, 2018; Hachaj, 2019; Hachaj & Szlapa, 2017) was
adapted in the current study. AdH is a 2D depth-averaged,
finite element, modelling tool for simulating hydrody-
namic conditions which uses the finite element method
to solve two-dimensional momentum conservation equa-
tions for water-in the Eulerian frame for both x and y
directions (Berger et al., 2010) according to Equation (2):
where: v x , v y -velocity components in and directions, re-
spectively (m/s); f x (m/s)-unitary force in the direction,
represented by wind-induced surface friction, wave impact;
f y (m/s)-unitary force (wind, waves…) in the y direction; C f
(1/s)-Coriolis factor; g (m/s)-gravitational acceleration, ϛ
(m)-water surface elevation, H (m)-depth, C (m½/s)-
Chezy roughness coefficient, v (m 2 /s) kinematic viscosity
coefficient, and p (Pa)-external pressure.
The bathymetric map and hydrologic data to set up the
hydrodynamic model for the Dobczyce Reservoir were
sourced from the reservoir management authority (State
Water Holding-Polish Waters). The boundary conditions
in the AdH module, i.e. inflow rate and water surface el-
evation level (WSE), were adapted to include monthly
Average High Flow (AHQ) (Luong et al., 2021; Wrzesiński
& Sobkowiak, 2020) and normal water surface level-
269.9 m a.s.l. The simulation was performed with the de-
fault bottom roughness parameter and water density, as
well as the neglected impact of wind, wave and Coriolis
forces. The AHQ values were calculated using flow data
simulated by the SWAT module for each variant scenario
according to Equation (3):
where: AHQ (m 3 /s)-average high flow for a given month,
Y (-)-number of years within the data series and max (Qd )
(m 3 /s)-the highest daily flow observed within a calendar
month (m index of AHQ and the max operator) of a given
year (y index of the max operator).
Particles inside of the Dobczyce Reservoir have been
tracked using the PTM module assuming that the output
of the SWAT model is the only source of particles intro-
duced into this reservoir. Since the Eulerian approach is
based on tracking a mass load while the Lagrangian one
uses a concept of tracking individual particles, thus, at
the connection point, a given mass load has to be trans-
formed into a given number of representative particles.
This issue has been solved by generating a number of rep-
resentative particles for each suspended sediment fraction
to be proportional to the appropriate mass load calculated
by the SWAT module for a given month (File 1_DATA_
SWAT). This source area was set as an ellipsoid with a
centre point at 1.9 m above the bottom and vertical and
horizontal radii of 1 and 25 m, respectively. These dimen-
sions were determined by the shape of the riverbed in the
place where the sediment source is located and allowed
for the maximum filling of the selected profile with the
shape of an ellipsoid. Simulations were performed using
sediment density of 2650 and 1240 kg/m 3 for mineral par-
ticles and mineral/organic aggregates, respectively (Czuba
et al., 2015). As for the particle diameter, the following val-
ues have been adopted: CLAY d = 0.002 mm (dev = 1.25),
SILT d = 0.05 mm (dev = 1.2), SMAG d = 0.03 mm (no de-
viation). Consequently, the particle distribution has been
followed in all four reservoir zones (A, B, C, D). Moreover,
the number of particles flowing downstream of the res-
ervoir (OUT) has been also tracked (File 2_DATA_AdH/
PTM).
2.4.2 | AdH/PTM models calibration and
validation
Since, the actual water velocity measurements with the
Dobczyce Reservoir were not available during the imple-
mentation of the hydrodynamic model consequently, the
so-called state-based approach to hydrodynamics has been
used. In this approach, in the absence of local quantitative

text.note: 20496060, 2024, 4, Downloaded from https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/gdj3.242 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
data the model should be consistent with reality on the
generalized qualitative level. Hydrodynamic features like
locations of currents and stagnant areas should appear
in the same regions of the reservoir and maintain similar
shapes. This approach involves formal logic and Markov
process formalism instead of functional analysis and sta-
tistics. This methodology has been used for the Dobczyce
Reservoir first by Bojarski et al. (2012) and then formal-
ized by Hachaj (2019).
The AdH model performance was assessed then by the
sensitivity analysis performed for the main variables ac-
countable for the model response to channel roughness
and wind forcing. As for the generalized Manning co-
efficient, the AdH model default value of 0.025 was ad-
opted in the current study. This value was adopted since
the differences among the modelled flow velocities along
the main current line were negligible for the coefficient
range of 0.0025-0.05, and only noticeable when the pa-
rameter value was set at an unreasonably high level of
0.25 (Figure 5).
As for the model response to the wind forcing, testing
was performed to verify the wind condition's impact on the
resulting velocity field. The impact of the wind appeared
to be important for low inflows (at the range of the modal
inflow, approx. 2 m 3 /s), but negligible for values higher
than the mean value for this reservoir (approx. 10 m 3 /s).
The AdH model simulation results for the Dobczyce
Reservoir were validated through comparison with pre-
viously observed reservoir features, like appearance of
current patterns and stagnant areas, as well as typical
transport times/velocities in the reservoir selected basins
(Hachaj, 2019). Ultimately, the state-based approach has
been validated on 208 velocity measurement points in an-
other storage reservoir (Włocławek) (Tutro et al., 2022)
reaching relative root mean square error (RRMSE) in a
range of 7.9*10 -5 and 1.6*10 -4 .
The PTM model validation was performed through
comparison between results of sediment deposition simu-
lation and grain distribution analyses for the dammed res-
ervoir bottom sediments (Szlapa, 2019) and localization
of progressive shallowing areas observed in satellite im-
ages for over 20 years (1997-2017) (Bojarski et al., 2012).
Comparison of granulometric analysis results (13 profiles
containing 3-4 sample points distributed evenly along the
reservoir) with the PTM simulations for SILT revealed a
PBIAS value of -21%, which signifies very good model
performance (Figure 6).
Moreover, superimposition of the simulation re-
sults with the bathymetric survey map of the Dobczyce
Reservoir showed a good reflection of sedimentation
F I G U R E 5 Simulated main current velocities (AdH model) in the Dobczyce Reservoir for different generalized Manning coefficient
values.
text.note: 20496060, 2024, 4, Downloaded from https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/gdj3.242 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
processes (localization of progressive shallows and grain
segregation along the reservoir) (Figure 7).
3 | RESULTS
The dataset entitled "Sediment particle distribution in a
dammed reservoir under climate and land use scenarios
(Carpathian Mts.)" is stored online, publicly available at
the Mendeley repository (https:// data. mende ley. com/
datas ets/ k9c7c 666bt/ 2). The file format is Excel files
(.xlsx). Additional maps displaying distribution of par-
ticles in the Dobczyce Reservoir with the monthly con-
ditions are also presented in this data set. The dataset
consists of three main parts (File 1_DATA_SWAT, File
2_DATA_AdH/PTM and File 3_Maps) which are di-
vided into sheets. The database flow has been presented
in Figure 8.
The calibrated and validated SWAT model for the
upper Raba River was used to run simulations for the
period of 13 years (2005-2017), considering both dry and
wet periods. Extracted data on flow simulations (FLOW
in m 3 /s) with the daily time step and the averaged sed-
iment fraction loads (CLAY, SILT and SMAG in tonnes/
month, t/m) with the monthly time step in the Myślenice
calculation profile for the baseline scenario are presented
in File 1_DATA_SWAT, sheet: SWAT-BASE. The obtained
results for the base scenario allow for tracking of the loads
of individual sediment fractions delivered to the reservoir
in particular months of the year and to indicate those in
which these loads reach high values.
The three analysed sediment fractions have different
monthly distributions; however, for all of them, two peri-
ods can be distinguished: October to April with low loads
and May to September with high loads. The high loads
reach 270, 891 and 3.3 t/m on average for CLAY, SILT and
SMAG in the period from May to August, respectively. In
general, the sediment loads introduced into the Dobczyce
Reservoir have been dominated by CLAY, with the maxi-
mum of loads delivered in June, constituting 66% of total
sediment loads in this month.
On the other hand, the effects of the implementation of
subsequent variant scenarios, combining climate and land
use changes affecting both flows and loads of individual
sediment fractions, can be tracked in File 1_DATA_SWAT,
sheets: SWAT-VS1-VS4. The column charts, as presented
for example in Figure 9, allow the user to easily compare
changes in the flow rates for the following months and
F I G U R E 6 Comparison of field observations (granulometric analysis) and PTM model simulations. SILT contribution in bed sediments
for the Dobczyce Reservoir profiles (%).
text.note: 20496060, 2024, 4, Downloaded from https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/gdj3.242 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
years. Moreover, the load changes for the analysed sed-
iment fraction could also be compared after selection of
appropriate options in these sheets. Generally, in the an-
alysed variant scenarios, different behaviour of particular
fractions has been observed. For the CLAY fraction loads,
an increase in winter and spring by even over 250% can
be observed. For SILT loads increase by 130%, in spring,
while for SMAG loads decrease in both seasons can be
noticed.
The results of the flow and the sediment simulations
converted into representative particles (as described in
Section 2.3.1) were used as input for the AdH/PTM mod-
elling part. This module allowed for the tracking of sed-
iment fractions' particles in the subsequent zones of the
dammed reservoir. In the File 2_DATA_AdHPTM, the
data were extracted for the coordinates (UTM Zone 34_
Northern Hemisphere) and of particles' diameters (mm)
assigned to the appropriate fractions. Moreover, their
deposition locations in the subsequent reservoir zones (A,
B, C and D) in the baseline (AdHPTM-BASE) and variant
scenarios (AdHPTM-VS1-4) have been given. In addition,
sediment particles that have been transported down-
stream from the reservoir (OUT) into the lower part of the
Raba River (designated as -9999.9 coordinates) are also
included in these sheets. The pivot column charts, as pre-
sented for example in Figure 10, allow the user to easily
compare the amount of deposited particles in each zone
of the reservoir (Figure 10).
The File 3_Maps constitutes a graphical supplement to
the tabular results presented in File 2_DATA_AdHPTM.
These maps allow the user to track the particles of anal-
ysed sediment fractions (differentiated by colours) in sub-
sequent zones of the dammed reservoir for each month
(JAN-DEC) and scenario (base and VS1-4). As presented
for example in Figure 11, visible changes in deposition
area for all the particle fractions can be observed for the
studied reservoir zones in April when base and VS4 sce-
narios are compared. Additionally, movement of SILT
and CLAY particles can be tracked through the mp4 file
(Video S1).
In general, our database shows that over 80% of all frac-
tions flowing into the studied reservoir will be deposited in
its two main reservoir's basins (zones C and D). However,
monthly cycle trends and response for implemented sce-
narios are different for each fraction. The SMAG presence
will be observed mainly from May till September and de-
posited in the backwater zone (B). The SILT fraction will
be deposited in autumn-spring in the river zone (A), but
F I G U R E 7 Superimposition of the bedforms obtained during the simulation with the results of the bathymetric survey of the Dobczyce
Reservoir.
text.note: 20496060, 2024, 4, Downloaded from https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/gdj3.242 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
in the backwater zone (B) in summer. The outflow of both
fractions from the reservoir will be negligible. In turn, the
CLAY particles will be transported downstream (OUT) in
summer, but in other seasons these particles will be depos-
ited in backwater (B) and Myślenice basin (C) zones. All
the climate scenarios will intensify these trends, and ex-
tend the deposition in summer-autumn period for SMAG
and SILT, and also will increase the outflow of CLAY from
the reservoir.
4 | POTENTIAL DATASET USE
AND REUSE
The paper presents a detailed description of the dataset
which enables tracking three fractions of sediment par-
ticles introduced from the mountainous river into the
dammed reservoir (Western Carpathians). The devel-
oped database results from an innovative combination of
models describing two hydrologically different elements
F I G U R E 8 Database structure.
F I G U R E 9 An example of a column chart for flows simulated by the SWAT module in the VS4 scenario in the Myślenice calculation
profile.
text.note: 20496060, 2024, 4, Downloaded from https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/gdj3.242 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
of the catchment, and operating together as modules on
a common digital platform-the Macromodel DNS. An
input data, i.e. sediment loads from the upper Raba River,
were obtained from the SWAT model. Moreover, apply-
ing variant scenarios, the impacts of climate and land
use changes on sediment fractions loads have also been
assessed. Subsequently, current and future deposition of
sediment particles in the reservoir has been tracked and
mapped with use of the AdH/PTM models. Moreover, it
should be noted that integration of SWAT and AdH/PTM
models under the umbrella of the Macromodel DNS digi-
tal platform also allowed to overcome the insufficient per-
formance of the reservoir module included in the SWAT
model itself, which currently allows only to establish loads
of particular sediment fractions delivered and released
from the reservoir.
The created database, consisting of both tabular and
graphic results, enables tracking current and future changes
in the particle transport from the source into the reser-
voir in the area exemplary for the Western Carpathians.
It provides mainly information on delivery of sediment
loads into the reservoir, deposition of individual sediment
fractions and outflow of sediment particles downstream
from the reservoir in particular months as well as climate
and land use change scenarios. Its use may therefore bring
tangible benefits to the water administration and other
F I G U R E 1 0 Example of a column chart for sediment particles (CLAY, SILT and SMAG) simulated by the AdH/PTM module in the VS4
scenario in subsequent zones of the dammed reservoir (A, B, C, D and OUT).
F I G U R E 1 1 Example of results visualization for sediment mineral fractions in April for the baseline scenario and VS4.
text.note: 20496060, 2024, 4, Downloaded from https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/gdj3.242 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
stakeholders of dammed reservoirs in this area, allowing
for the planning of appropriate management actions re-
sponsible for providing comprehensive perspectives and
formulating effective strategies for maintaining the reser-
voir functionality in the future, e.g. indicating shallowing
to avoid them in recreation planning as well as preparing
for future sediment removal tasks. The presented maps of
sediment particle deposition sites in subsequent reservoir
zones also enable the selection of specific sampling points
for research, taking into account their annual variabil-
ity. The collected information may also help to develop
risk assessment and risk mitigation strategies for reser-
voir catchment facing future climate change challenges.
Moreover, the results obtained on their basis may consti-
tute valuable information for the construction and analy-
sis of the results of subsequent environmental models for
the catchment of the analysed area. Furthermore, since
our approach constitutes a unique one in the context of
combining different modelling tools, our data give catch-
ment modellers a ready-to-use tool to observe and analyse
effects on sediment transport induced by the climate and
land use changes in settings of a full-scale reservoir local-
ized in a mountainous catchment.
The presented dataset is an important supplement to
the sediment transport studies, but it also has some limita-
tions, described in detail in Wilk et al. (2022). It should be
mentioned that the current database provides a qualitative
information on sediment transport in the study venue,
while quantitative one will be the goal of further research.
text.div:
ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
The study was performed out as part of the
Interdisciplinary Research Group-Pollutant Transport
in a Catchment (http:// ochrs rod. agh. edu. pl/ index. html)
activity. It was supported by the program "Excellence ini-
tiative-research university" for the AGH University of
Krakow, AGH University (sub. 16.16.140.315), Cracow
University of Technology (2020 sub. for the Department
of Geoengineering Water Management) and Institute of
Meteorology and Water Management (sub. FBW-6 and 7).
OPEN RESEARCH BADGES
This article has been awarded Open Data Badge for mak-
ing publicly available the digistally-shareable data neces-
sary to reproduce the reported results. Data is available at
Open Science Framework.

DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
The SWAT model dataset (version 2012.10_2.19) was de-
rived for the years 1991-2017 at the catchment level with
a monthly time step. The data included map of Poland
hydrographical divisions, digital elevation model (DEM),
land use map based on Corine Land Cover, soil map with
detailed data on soil types, meteorological data for 75 sta-
tions located directly in the catchment, and within 20
km from its borders, and surface water quality data for
suspended sediment. Two additional modules have been
incorporated into the DNS digital platform. Hydraulic con-
ditions for sediment load scenarios have been modeled
with the use of the AdH module, while the particle trans-
port has been simulated with the use of the PTM module
created with use of the following data: numerical model
of the Dobczyce Reservoir bottom and backwater shape
updated bathymetry map. The dataset called "Sediment
particle distribution in a dammed reservoir under climate
and land use scenarios (Carpathian Mts.)" is stored in the
online, publicly available Mendeley data research data ar-
chive, https:// data. mende ley. com/ datas ets/ k9c7c 666bt/ 2
(Hachaj et al., 2022).
